natural problem: If $$1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101 \equiv n\pmod{15},$$where $0\le n<15$, what is the value of $n$?
natural solution: Replacing each term in the sum by a modulo 15 equivalent, we have \begin{align} &1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\qquad\equiv 1+6+11+1+6+11+\cdots+1+6+11 \pmod{15}, \end{align}where the terms $1+6+11$ are repeated $7$ times on the right.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "n = (\<Sum> i=0..<20. 1 + 5*i) mod 15"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "n < 15"
shows  "n = 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $$1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101 \equiv n\pmod{15},$$where $0\le n<15$, what is the value of $n$? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Replacing each term in the sum by a modulo 15 equivalent, we have \begin{align} &1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\qquad\equiv 1+6+11+1+6+11+\cdots+1+6+11 \pmod{15}, \end{align}where the terms $1+6+11$ are repeated $7$ times on the right.
 Since $1+6+11=18\equiv 3\pmod{15}$, we have \begin{align} 1+6+11&+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\equiv \underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\cdots+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3 \\ &\equiv 7\cdot 3 \\ &= 21 \\
 &\equiv \boxed{6}\pmod{15}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "n = (\<Sum> i=0..<20. 1 + 5*i) mod 15"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "n < 15"
shows  "n = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the remainder when the sum of the first 20 terms of the arithmetic sequence that starts with 1 and increases by 5 each term, is divided by 15. The final answer is 6.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "sum (\<lambda>i. 1 + 5 * i) {0..20} mod 15 = n"
and h1 : "0 \<le> n"
and h2 : "n < 15"
shows  "n = 6"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $$1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101 \equiv n\pmod{15},$$where $0\le n<15$, what is the value of $n$? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Replacing each term in the sum by a modulo 15 equivalent, we have \begin{align} &1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\qquad\equiv 1+6+11+1+6+11+\cdots+1+6+11 \pmod{15}, \end{align}where the terms $1+6+11$ are repeated $7$ times on the right.
 Since $1+6+11=18\equiv 3\pmod{15}$, we have \begin{align} 1+6+11&+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\equiv \underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\cdots+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3 \\ &\equiv 7\cdot 3 \\ &= 21 \\
 &\equiv \boxed{6}\pmod{15}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "sum (\<lambda>i. 1 + 5 * i) {0..20} mod 15 = n"
and h1 : "0 \<le> n"
and h2 : "n < 15"
shows  "n = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: What is the remainder when the sum of the series $1 + 5i$ from $i = 0$ to $20$ is divided by $15$? The final answer is $6$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "a 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> n > 0. a n = a (n-1) + 5"
and h2 : "101 = a m"
and h3 : "n = sum a {0..m} mod 15"
shows  "n = 6"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $$1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101 \equiv n\pmod{15},$$where $0\le n<15$, what is the value of $n$? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Replacing each term in the sum by a modulo 15 equivalent, we have \begin{align} &1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\qquad\equiv 1+6+11+1+6+11+\cdots+1+6+11 \pmod{15}, \end{align}where the terms $1+6+11$ are repeated $7$ times on the right.
 Since $1+6+11=18\equiv 3\pmod{15}$, we have \begin{align} 1+6+11&+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\equiv \underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\cdots+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3 \\ &\equiv 7\cdot 3 \\ &= 21 \\
 &\equiv \boxed{6}\pmod{15}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "a 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> n > 0. a n = a (n-1) + 5"
and h2 : "101 = a m"
and h3 : "n = sum a {0..m} mod 15"
shows  "n = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A sequence $a$ is defined recursively by $a(0)=1$ and $a(n)=a(n-1)+5$ for all positive integers $n$. If $a(m)=101$ and $n$ is the sum of all terms from $a(0)$ to $a(m)$ modulo 15, what is the value of $n$? The final answer is 6.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int and sum :: int
assumes h0 : "sum = (\<Sum> i=0..20. 1 + 5*i)"
and h1 : "n = sum mod 15"
and h2 : "0 \<le> n"
and h3 : "n < 15"
shows  "n = 6"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $$1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101 \equiv n\pmod{15},$$where $0\le n<15$, what is the value of $n$? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Replacing each term in the sum by a modulo 15 equivalent, we have \begin{align} &1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\qquad\equiv 1+6+11+1+6+11+\cdots+1+6+11 \pmod{15}, \end{align}where the terms $1+6+11$ are repeated $7$ times on the right.
 Since $1+6+11=18\equiv 3\pmod{15}$, we have \begin{align} 1+6+11&+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\equiv \underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\cdots+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3 \\ &\equiv 7\cdot 3 \\ &= 21 \\
 &\equiv \boxed{6}\pmod{15}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int and sum :: int
assumes h0 : "sum = (\<Sum> i=0..20. 1 + 5*i)"
and h1 : "n = sum mod 15"
and h2 : "0 \<le> n"
and h3 : "n < 15"
shows  "n = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the remainder when the sum of the first 20 terms of the arithmetic sequence that starts with 1 and increases by 5 each term is divided by 15. The final answer is 6.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "n = (\<Sum>k\<leftarrow>[1..21]. 5 * k - 4) mod 15"
shows  "n = 6"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $$1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101 \equiv n\pmod{15},$$where $0\le n<15$, what is the value of $n$? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Replacing each term in the sum by a modulo 15 equivalent, we have \begin{align} &1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\qquad\equiv 1+6+11+1+6+11+\cdots+1+6+11 \pmod{15}, \end{align}where the terms $1+6+11$ are repeated $7$ times on the right.
 Since $1+6+11=18\equiv 3\pmod{15}$, we have \begin{align} 1+6+11&+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\equiv \underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\cdots+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3 \\ &\equiv 7\cdot 3 \\ &= 21 \\
 &\equiv \boxed{6}\pmod{15}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "n = (\<Sum>k\<leftarrow>[1..21]. 5 * k - 4) mod 15"
shows  "n = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the remainder when the sum of the first 21 terms of the arithmetic series, each term given by $5k - 4$, is divided by 15. The final answer is 6.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "(\<Sum>k=0..20. 1 + 5*k) mod 15 = n"
and h1 : "0 \<le> n"
and h2 : "n < 15"
shows  "n = 6"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 &\equiv \boxed{6}\pmod{15}. \end{align}

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "(\<Sum>k=0..20. 1 + 5*k) mod 15 = n"
and h1 : "0 \<le> n"
and h2 : "n < 15"
shows  "n = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the remainder when the sum of the first 21 terms of the arithmetic sequence $1, 6, 11, \ldots$ is divided by 15. The final answer is 6.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "(\<Sum>k=0..20. 1 + 5 * k) mod 15 = n"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "n < 15"
shows  "n = 6"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $$1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101 \equiv n\pmod{15},$$where $0\le n<15$, what is the value of $n$? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof

 Since $1+6+11=18\equiv 3\pmod{15}$, we have \begin{align} 1+6+11&+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\equiv \underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\cdots+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3 \\ &\equiv 7\cdot 3 \\ &= 21 \\
 &\equiv \boxed{6}\pmod{15}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "(\<Sum>k=0..20. 1 + 5 * k) mod 15 = n"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "n < 15"
shows  "n = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the remainder when the sum of the first 21 terms of the arithmetic sequence beginning with 1 and increasing by 5 each term is divided by 15. The final answer is 6.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "sum (\<lambda>i. 5 * i - 4) {1..21} mod 15 = n"
and h1 : "0 \<le> n"
and h2 : "n < 15"
shows  "n = 6"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $$1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101 \equiv n\pmod{15},$$where $0\le n<15$, what is the value of $n$? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Replacing each term in the sum by a modulo 15 equivalent, we have \begin{align} &1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\qquad\equiv 1+6+11+1+6+11+\cdots+1+6+11 \pmod{15}, \end{align}where the terms $1+6+11$ are repeated $7$ times on the right.
 Since $1+6+11=18\equiv 3\pmod{15}$, we have \begin{align} 1+6+11&+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\equiv \underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\cdots+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3 \\ &\equiv 7\cdot 3 \\ &= 21 \\
 &\equiv \boxed{6}\pmod{15}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "sum (\<lambda>i. 5 * i - 4) {1..21} mod 15 = n"
and h1 : "0 \<le> n"
and h2 : "n < 15"
shows  "n = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the remainder when the sum of the first 21 terms of the sequence defined by $5n - 4$ is divided by 15. The final answer is 6.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "∀i. 1 ≤ i ∧ i ≤ 21 ⟶ (1 + 5 * i) mod 15 = n"
shows  "n = 6"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $$1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101 \equiv n\pmod{15},$$where $0\le n<15$, what is the value of $n$? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Replacing each term in the sum by a modulo 15 equivalent, we have \begin{align} &1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\qquad\equiv 1+6+11+1+6+11+\cdots+1+6+11 \pmod{15}, \end{align}where the terms $1+6+11$ are repeated $7$ times on the right.
 Since $1+6+11=18\equiv 3\pmod{15}$, we have \begin{align} 1+6+11&+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\equiv \underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\cdots+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3 \\ &\equiv 7\cdot 3 \\ &= 21 \\
 &\equiv \boxed{6}\pmod{15}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "∀i. 1 ≤ i ∧ i ≤ 21 ⟶ (1 + 5 * i) mod 15 = n"
shows  "n = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the remainder, n, when the expression 1 + 5i is divided by 15 for all integers i between 1 and 21, inclusive. The final answer is 6.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "(\<Sum>i=1..21. 1 + 5 * (i - 1)) mod 15 = n"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "n < 15"
shows  "n = 6"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If $$1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101 \equiv n\pmod{15},$$where $0\le n<15$, what is the value of $n$? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Replacing each term in the sum by a modulo 15 equivalent, we have \begin{align} &1+6+11+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\qquad\equiv 1+6+11+1+6+11+\cdots+1+6+11 \pmod{15}, \end{align}where the terms $1+6+11$ are repeated $7$ times on the right.
 Since $1+6+11=18\equiv 3\pmod{15}$, we have \begin{align} 1+6+11&+16+21+26+\cdots+91+96+101\\ &\equiv \underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3+\cdots+\underbrace{1+6+11}_3 \\ &\equiv 7\cdot 3 \\ &= 21 \\
 &\equiv \boxed{6}\pmod{15}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "(\<Sum>i=1..21. 1 + 5 * (i - 1)) mod 15 = n"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 0"
and h2 : "n < 15"
shows  "n = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the remainder when the sum of the first 21 terms of the arithmetic sequence beginning at 1 and increasing by 5 at each step is divided by 15. The final answer is 6.
